https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/97695/ : SUCCESS

More pieces that can go in common layer -
- EM interface for device and package configs and related classes.
- PLDM package verification and related classes.
closing this since the pldm package parsing and verification is now part of common folder.
Do we really need to keep this interface definition separate?
no, we can merge the 2 classes 👍
Whats the purpose of this arg?
dry run - this enables us to do testing of the update flow without actually writing to the device. It is useful for debug purposes and can be disabled by default.
Something which is common for i2c and is generic, let's move that to common/i2c.
yes, this was simply code copied from the meta openbmc to make the VR stuff compile. When i rewrite it in terms of LF openbmc i2c code i can put it into common. I'll resolve when i moved it.

removed the voltage regulator update daemon from this patchset.
It can go into a later patchset.
I think this is some sort of persistent key value store, i don't think we need this?
we don't need it, this was just copied from meta openbmc to make the vr code compile. I'll resolve when i removed it.

removed the voltage regulator update daemon from this patchset.
It can go into a later patchset.
Let's move to sdbusplus::async::context.
done 👍
I dont think we need any of the read APIs?
Done

still working on the common code.

With this revision, i added the 'Device' class which can be extended by the device specific update daemons.

While the 'FWManager' class represents an updater daemon for the class of devices,
the 'Device' class represents a single physical device.

So it can own a mutex for updating the device and also any device specific 
properties.


The 'Software' class still represents the set of dbus interfaces to be maintained for a software version running on the device or being applied to the device.
Two smaller nits.
Some on thing here, other naming may be more accurately.
Done

"my_sw_update" may not be the ideal name for the class or the file.

Suggestions: 
- "bios_fw_update_process"
- "bios_fw_process"

This may indicate a more accurately what the class is about. 
Other suggestions welcome as well.
Yes. Renamed that to spi_device_sw_update and spi_device_sw since it's not limited to bios update but targets any sw stored on spi flash.

Why are you placing create PLDM package APIs in the common layer, ideally they should be available in a tools dir? The common layer should only have the logic to parse the package because thats what is needed on the device.

It is also needed for unit testing the package parsing code and for the tool to create a minimal pldm package for testing. We can put it in a tools directory to separate it from the common code for the code updaters.

Keeping this comment open since i'm planning to address this in a future revision.
moved the code to 'tool' directory.
Update/aserver.hpp?
Done
Why there is a normal and async version of the startUpdate?

startUpdate is implemented in device.cpp and is called to start the async update.
The async update is implemented by each code updater.

'startUpdate' is marked final for this reason, since the code updaters should not override it.
Why is everything public in this class?
sorry about that. Updated it to have public, protected and private members.
Same comment as SoftwareVersion.
Done
Also, rather than creating individual objects, do you think it will be better to create composite server object if they are going to be used at the same place?

I prefer to have more objects with fewer methods each. Inheriting from all these dbus interfaces means there is many methods on the object.

Having more smaller classes helps also when passing them by reference. It is clear that the function receiving that reference is only updating e.g. the ActivationProgress interface.

Agree that it's a lot of classes though.
Same comment as SoftwareVersion.
Done
Again, please move this constructor to .hpp file.

why? I always thought we use .cpp for implementation and .hpp for declarations.

If we have implementations in header files, they may be compiled multiple times and then need to be deduplicated, right?
made the Software class inherit from the association definitions, so this file is now gone.
As per my understanding you just need one instance of server manager somewhere at the root of the objectPath and not on every instance of every interface.
ok, removed it here.
Why do we need a cpp file? If u r just defining the constructor, better to do it in header?

We normally don't pass the debug flag this way. You can keep the logs at debug level and change the log level to debug to get those messages.

Let's drop this from the interface.

We are using this currently in SPIDevice Code Updater to decide if we want to delete the component image.

With this flag the code updater can run in debug mode and behave differently to make it easier to debug. One example of this is to leave behind any components extracted from the pldm package, so people can verify that the component was extracted correctly.

If it were only about printing debug logs then we could drop it.

But i want to give the code updater the chance to behave differently when in debug mode.

Why do you need to store what tool is being used to flash in the EM - Are you planning to support multiple types of tool for same type of firmware update, if yes, whats the advantage of that? I think these details should be internal to the daemon?

Yes, internal logic/library call is preferred to using any external tool.

>  Are you planning to support multiple types of tool for same type of firmware update, if yes, whats the advantage of that?

It's in SoftwareManager, it has 
```
SoftwareManager::getInitialConfiguration()
```
and then calls a component specific implementation to decide further.

So the user code can decide if the device should really be created or not.

The common configuration options 'DeviceConfig' are passed to the user code so it does not need to be parsed there.

The point of this is to allow for any custom logic in the user code
which is getInitialConfigurationSingleDevice.

Software Activation is the first interface you create as part of StartUpdate in a sync order. at that time you don't know the version yet, as image hasn't been parsed yet, so you cannot create the Version and other interfaces. So, i would suggest to create a composite for Version and associations only and create activation interface early. Activation interface is the one you need to change in case your image parsing and verification logic fails. Please refer to sequence diagram in design.

> Software Activation is the first interface you create as part of StartUpdate in a sync order. at that time you don't know the version yet, as image hasn't been parsed yet, so you cannot create the Version and other interfaces.

Yes, the activation interface on the object path is probably needed for the bmcweb, and we should not create the other interfaces without having the property values.

> So, i would suggest to create a composite for Version and associations only

For now i'm representing it as unique_ptr on the software object, so we do not have to create another object here for these dbus interfaces.
When 'Software' class is initialized, these can be nullptr, and then later be
populated when the information is available.

The latest patchset should set the activation status synchronously during the dbus call.

I would suggest its better to hide this in common layer by creating it for ActivationStatus = Activating and deleting it when ActivationStatus = Active. You already have API for setActivation, so its better to do it internally as part of that?

It is tempting...

There may be devices who do not need this 'ActivationBlocksTransition' interface. Those devices can make a state transition independent of any firmware update.
For example devices with A/B schema.

So i would like to avoid coupling the two in the common code.
Currently they are still coupled but there could be a different requirement in the future.

Also, it is easier for me to see that the code in device.cpp follows the design, when the
`setActivationBlocksTransition` is done as a separate function.
One can go step by step through the design and have roughly a 1:1 mapping between
statements in the functions in device.cpp and the steps outlined in the design.

Keeping this comment as unresolved here if you want to discuss further.

Please use the documented associations from 

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/code-update.md#association

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Software/Version.interface.yaml#L47

Activation in Progress : activating association.
SW Running: running association.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Feedback from Chris,

here we need to check for multiple different configuration types.
For example here https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/14debea1086b867d718a9cdfca0d9f52b6bd8bce/configurations/harma_mb_vr_infineon.json#L1098

The voltage regulators have "Type": "XDPE152C4"
but other voltage regulators will have other "Type" field.

Since the voltage regulator code updater should cover all of these,

'getConfigurationInterface()' needs to change to something like
'getConfigurationInterfaces()' and return a std::set of configuration interfaces.

And since that's implemented in common code, we need to change
this->configType

to be 

this->configTypes and it should be std::set.

This is only one alternative to do it but the current code does not work for supporting multiple EM config 'Type'  without the common prefix.
